<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_uint8_to_str_pad:
```c
size_t
MHD_uint8_to_str_pad (uint8_t val,
                      uint8_t min_digits,
                      char *buf,
                      size_t buf_size)
{
  size_t pos; /**< the position of the current printed digit */
  int digit;
  mhd_assert (3 >= min_digits);
  if (0 == buf_size)
    return 0;

  pos = 0;
  digit = val / 100;
  if (0 == digit)
  {
    if (3 <= min_digits)
      buf[pos++] = '0';
  }
  else
  {
    buf[pos++] = (char) ('0' + (char) digit);
    val %= 100;
    min_digits = 2;
  }

  if (buf_size <= pos)
    return 0;
  digit = val / 10;
  if (0 == digit)
  {
    if (2 <= min_digits)
      buf[pos++] = '0';
  }
  else
  {
    buf[pos++] = (char) ('0' + (char) digit);
    val %= 10;
  }

  if (buf_size <= pos)
    return 0;
  buf[pos++] = (char) ('0' + (char) val);
  return pos;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_uint8_to_str_pad:
size_t
MHD_uint16_to_str (uint16_t val,
                   char *buf,
                   size_t buf_size)
{
  char *chr;  /**< pointer to the current printed digit */
  /* The biggest printable number is 65535 */
  uint16_t divisor = UINT16_C (10000);
  int digit;

  chr = buf;
  digit = (int) (val / divisor);
  mhd_assert (digit < 10);

  /* Do not print leading zeros */
  while ((0 == digit) && (1 < divisor))
  {
    divisor /= 10;
    digit = (int) (val / divisor);
    mhd_assert (digit < 10);
  }

  while (0 != buf_size)
  {
    *chr = (char) ((char) digit + '0');
    chr++;
    buf_size--;
    if (1 == divisor)
      return (size_t) (chr - buf);
    val = (uint16_t) (val % divisor);
    divisor /= 10;
    digit = (int) (val / divisor);
    mhd_assert (digit < 10);
  }
  return 0; /* The buffer is too small */
}
</additional code>

explanation:
No calls to the <string.h> string handling functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) are present in the provided code. Rule 21.17 specifically targets use of those standard library string functions and their potential to access beyond object bounds; therefore the rule is not directly applicable to these fragments.

Furthermore, the direct buffer writes in MHD_uint8_to_str_pad are preceded by an initial buf_size == 0 check and subsequent checks of pos against buf_size before further writes, so the function’s own bounds checks prevent out-of-bounds writes in normal operation. In MHD_uint16_to_str, writes to *chr occur only inside a loop guarded by while (0 != buf_size) and buf_size is decremented on each write, so the loop control prevents overwriting beyond the provided buffer size. These behaviors address the out-of-bounds risks that Rule 21.17 is concerned with for string library calls.

Note: General concerns such as passing a NULL buf with a non-zero buf_size, or other API-contract violations, are outside the scope of MISRA C:2023 Rule 21.17 (which is limited to the standard <string.h> functions) and therefore were not flagged here.
